text: (Platts)--24Nov2025/703 am EST/1203 GMT **Alternative fuels reach 13.2% of Rotterdam bunker sales in Q3 **IMO Net-Zero Framework delay hampers industry transition **Dutch port adds LNG, biofuel storage and shorepower networks The Dutch port of Rotterdam is pushing ahead with infrastructure expansion for sustainable marine energy, but global decarbonization rules would be required for an industry-wide low-carbon bunker transition, the port's Chief Operating Officer Berte Simons, told Platts, part of S&P Global Energy. LNG and biofuel bunker sales at Rotterdam, the world's second-largest marine refueling hub, have been on an upward trend in recent years, with the port authority kickstarting its pursuit of climate neutrality by 2050. The port reported 2.45 million metric tons of marine fuel sales during July-September, of which alternatives to conventional, oil-based fuels accounted for 13.2%, the highest among major bunker ports. Deliveries of biofuels, composed mainly of biodiesel-fuel oil blends, reached 201,319 mt, and fossil LNG amounted to 121,614 mt. "For the next few years, we will have LNG there together with new green fuels for quite some time," Simons said in a recent interview. "We have set out to increase the volume of biofuels and to come up with bunkering facilities for new fuels, to work on imports and exports and bunkering strategies for hydrogen, ammonia and methanol." The continued efforts to decarbonize Rotterdam's bunker mix came despite International Maritime Organization member states voting in mid-October to postpone the Net-Zero Framework by a year, Platts reported earlier. The proposed regulation, backed by the Netherlands and nearly all other EU states, was designed to promote the uptake of low-carbon fuels by placing a cost on maritime greenhouse gas emissions from 2028. "The postponement of the adoption of the IMO's Net-Zero Framework is a major setback," Simons said. "The absence of a global level playing field, long term perspective and limited demand for sustainable transportation make it difficult to scale and remain competitive." Brussels has extended its Emissions Trading System to cover shipping from 2024, while introducing FuelEU Maritime rules on marine energy's greenhouse gas intensity in January, pushing up total refueling expenses for ships in EU-related trades. October's average delivered bunker costs for B30 with 30% used cooking oil methyl ester in Rotterdam were $841.70/mt for ships sailing to a non-EU port, according to the Platts bunker cost calculator. Costs for B24 were $728.46/mt in Singapore, the world's largest bunker port, for ships on voyages to an EU port. DEVELOPMENTS AT ROTTERDAM Rotterdam, the top European port by cargo throughput, is undergoing several expansion projects for LNG and biofuel tanks. At the Gate terminal, a new LNG storage tank of 180,000 cu m and additional regasification capacity of 4 bank cubic meters per year is due to be operational by the second half of 2026. Bunker supplier Peninsula will add eight tanks with a total capacity of 80,000 cu m to its biofuel storage and blending facilities in Chane Terminal next January, bringing its total capacity to 110,000 cu m. Rotterdam currently handles 2 million mt/year of methanol and 400,000 mt/year of ammonia, predominantly made from fossil fuels, but those would lay the foundation for the transition to sustainable methanol and ammonia bunkering, according to Simons. The port has been piloting methanol bunkering projects. In April, Trammo completed a ship-to-ship transfer of 800 cu m of ammonia at OCI's terminal in preparation for future ammonia bunkering. In October, OCI signed a memorandum of understanding with Victrol for ammonia bunkering in Rotterdam, Platts reported earlier. "We are also preparing for bunkering of liquid hydrogen for short-sea shipping," Simons said. "We are focused on having the infrastructure for new bunker fuels." However, the executive stressed that the marine energy transition would depend on the supply-demand fundamentals for green fuels, whose prices are higher than conventional fuels due to limited production. "Real growth in the uptake of sustainable fuels depends on clear, consistent, and global regulation," Simons said. "The Net-Zero Framework provides a crucial step forward — so we hope next year the NZF will be adopted." SHORESIDE POWER Simons said Rotterdam has 10 berths for ocean-going ships installed with shoreside power charging network and 100 cabinets for inland shipping, with plans for further expansion. Based on EU regulations, container and passenger ships must be connected to charging facilities by 2030 at the main EU ports listed in the trans-European transport network, including Rotterdam. The ports, in turn, are required to develop the infrastructure to meet 90% of ship operators' demand. While inland ships can be fully electrified due to limited space for on-board battery systems, large, ocean-going ships could be designed or retrofitted to run on power at berth and turn off their auxiliary engines during "cold-ironing," leading to lower marine fuel use and CO2 emissions as well as less air pollution. "At the moment we have only a few OPS installations operational for cruise, ferries, offshore and smaller vessels. We are, however, fully on track to realize installations at the container terminals that will bring us to compliance," Simons said, adding that the port's estimated planned capacity in 2030 will be well over 150 MW. Rotterdam has established a joint venture with Eneco, Rotterdam Shore Power, to execute shoreside power projects in coordination with government-owned grid operators for terminals. Terminal operators can also develop their own charging systems. Ships could pay a fee per kilowatt-hour based on wholesale pricings — a model more relevant to inland shipping — or shipping companies could sign electricity supply deals with terminal firms, according to Simons. — Max Lin, Max.Lin@ihsmarkit.com-- Edited by Anoop Menon, newsdesk@spglobal.com--Platts Electricity Alert--

Rotterdam has established a joint venture with Eneco, Rotterdam Shore Power, to execute shoreside power projects in coordination with government-owned grid operators for terminals. Terminal operators can also develop their own charging systems. Ships could pay a fee per kilowatt-hour based on wholesale pricings — a model more relevant to inland shipping — or shipping companies could sign electricity supply deals with terminal firms, according to Simons. — Max Lin, Max.Lin@ihsmarkit.com-- Edited by Anoop Menon, newsdesk@spglobal.com--Platts Electricity Alert--

title: MARBEM: Moving “beyond methane” toward true net-zero shipping - SAFETY4SEA
authors: The Editorial Team, Dr. Sian Prior
description:
The organization – MARBEM (Maritime Beyond Methane) – advocates for a ‘beyond methane’ mindset, arguing that this approach will enable the maritime sector to transition toward long-term solutions capable of achieving net-zero emissions.
SAFETY4SEA: What was the main motivation behind launching Maritime Beyond Methane (MARBEM), and what gap does it fill in current maritime decarbonization efforts?
The motivation for Maritime Beyond Methane (MARBEM) is to provide clarity and alignment around maritime decarbonization pathways.
S4S: How does MARBEM define “beyond methane” — and what fuels or technologies does the initiative consider truly future-ready?
Let’s also consider that approximately 38% of global maritime trade volume is currently dedicated to oil and gas transport (UNCTAD, 2024).
text:
In an exclusive interview with Lukas Leppert, Transport Policy Officer at NABU, and Dr. Sian Prior, Lead Advisor to the Clean Arctic Alliance, we explore the vision behind a newly launched organization designed to bring clarity and alignment to maritime decarbonization pathways.

The organization – MARBEM (Maritime Beyond Methane) – advocates for a ‘beyond methane’ mindset, arguing that this approach will enable the maritime sector to transition toward long-term solutions capable of achieving net-zero emissions. While significant regulatory intervention is still lacking, the experts emphasize that pursuing a methane-free future would help create a resilient, future-proof maritime industry. They also outline their plans to strengthen the integrity of global decarbonization efforts.

SAFETY4SEA: What was the main motivation behind launching Maritime Beyond Methane (MARBEM), and what gap does it fill in current maritime decarbonization efforts?

The motivation for Maritime Beyond Methane (MARBEM) is to provide clarity and alignment around maritime decarbonization pathways. The current landscape is dominated by regulatory uncertainty and fragmented policies, enabling pseudo solutions – such as methane-based fuels – to gain market share, without regulators fully accounting for the long-term political, financial, economic, health and social risks. MARBEM fills this gap by providing independent, evidence-based analyses and expert insights to help decision-makers assess material risks, understand transition pathways, and establish 1.5 °C-aligned regulatory and environmental objectives.

S4S: What are your top priorities for the next five years?

Over the next five years, a central priority is to inform regulatory clarity and strengthen accountability for methane emissions within the IMO’s mid-term strategy and within regional regulatory frameworks, such as FuelEU. We want to establish comprehensive regulatory frameworks that:

Adopt measured, evidence-based LNG emission factors from well-to-wake to ensure alignment with real-world performance data.

Account for methane’s full climate and societal impacts in the Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) guidelines, including its short-term warming potential (GWP20), as well as associated leakage, environmental, and health externalities.

Prevent market distortion by avoiding incentives or crediting mechanisms that reward LNG as a transitional fuel despite its climate risks.

Expand control measures to address all methane emission sources onboard ships, covering main and auxiliary engines, and also fugitive and process-related emissions.

Encourage economic measures that enable a Just and Equitable Transition and uphold the polluter-pays principle.

If we can strengthen the integrity of decarbonization efforts, we can move the sector tangibly towards true net-zero emissions. In our work to reduce the impact of emissions of super-pollutants from shipping in the Arctic, we want to urgently reduce black carbon emissions by moving to cleaner fuels but in doing so avoid moving from oil-based fuels to gas-based fuels i.e. LNG which would simply result in reducing emissions of one super-pollutant (black carbon) but increasing emissions of another (methane).

S4S: How does MARBEM define “beyond methane” — and what fuels or technologies does the initiative consider truly future-ready?

“Beyond methane” reflects a transition toward long-term solutions that are capable of achieving net-zero emissions. To achieve this, fuels and technologies must be climate-aligned, regulation-ready, and capable of delivering genuine decarbonization outcomes across their full life cycle. Methane is a super-pollutant, with a global warming potential 82.5 times that of CO₂ over 20 years and 29.8 times over 100 years. Its atmospheric concentration has more than doubled in the past two centuries, contributing an estimated 20–30% of observed global warming. In maritime transport, methane-based fuels – including fossil, bio, and e-LNG – remain the primary source of methane emissions, with these rising 180% between 2016 and 2023 from LNG-fuelled ships.

S4S: The maritime sector already hosts numerous decarbonization alliances — what distinguishes MARBEM’s approach or methodology from others?

Our work connects the micro-level analysis of methane-based fuels with the macro-level context of global decarbonization policy and finance. We focus on bridging the gap between high-level climate ambitions and practical decision-making by translating complex technical and academic research into actionable items for policymakers, financiers, and industry leaders. Unlike many initiatives that adopt a neutral approach, MARBEM provides clarity by identifying both what is and what is not a viable long-term solution. Understanding pseudo-solutions and “non-solutions” is essential to effective risk management — it enables decision-makers to avoid investments and policies that may increase exposure to stranded assets, regulatory misalignment, or reputational risk. Our evidence-based approach emphasizes data, measurability, and regulatory relevance and scenarios to support the sector to align investment and policy choices with scientifically grounded, net-zero pathways.

S4S: What are the most promising zero-emission fuel pathways MARBEM sees emerging as alternatives to LNG and other methane-based fuels?

From a precautionary and energy-centric perspective—rather than a narrow, fuel-centric one—wind propulsion and electrification technologies stand out as the most promising zero-emission and low-cost energy pathways for shipping. By delivering propulsive energy directly to the vessel, wind propulsion removes the climate, environmental, and social externalities associated with fuel life cycles, including extraction, production, and distribution. Energy efficiency is an underutilized tool with great potential to reduce emissions while cutting operational costs. This recent World Bank publication demonstrates that improving energy efficiency can reduce global shipping’s GHG emissions by up to roughly 40% by 2030 – surpassing the IMO’s current interim targets – while also cutting the overall cost of the transition, with annual savings of up to $220 billion. Let’s also consider that approximately 38% of global maritime trade volume is currently dedicated to oil and gas transport (UNCTAD, 2024). As the world is making the transition toward a zero-emissions future, we have a unique opportunity to rethink trade structures, volumes and cargoes at a systems level. Global trade will remain necessary but sourcing goods more locally and restructuring regionally can help to create a sector that is able to operate within planetary boundaries.

S4S: With the IMO’s delay in adopting the Net-Zero Framework, how do you see MARBEM contributing to a stronger and more inclusive outcome over the next year?

This one-year delay opens an opportunity for greater clarity, alignment, and integrity in the end result. Over the next year, we will focus on developing independent analyses, case studies and reports to increase political awareness of the myriad of risks associated with methane-based fuels in the shipping sector. Providing this data will allow member states to come to an informed decision while also ensuring the adopted framework achieves tangible GHG reductions and delivers on its goals. We need to focus on evidence and transparency, with specific emphasis on real-world data that accurately accounts for methane’s climate impacts and market realities. By translating complex technical and policy insights into clear, actionable analyses, we aim to support member states with their role in strengthening the framework.

S4S: What innovations in ship design, retrofitting, and fuel infrastructure would you like to see in the coming years?

For progress to be meaningful, ship design, retrofitting, and fuel infrastructure improvements must be guided by a systems-level approach—one that integrates climate, biodiversity, pollution prevention, and a just and equitable transition. We have seen how addressing shipping impacts in silos has led to fragmented and sometimes counterproductive responses to policies. For instance, measures aimed at reducing air pollution delivered the required reductions in SOx pollution but allowed shipping companies to circumvent the intended solutions – moving to cleaner fuels – and resulted in increasing ocean pollution with the use of scrubbers. A similar risk is created with onboard carbon capture and storage (OCCS) since it will prolong use of fossil fuels instead of steering investments towards sustainable long-term solutions.Innovation has to be comprehensive. Its objective should be to simultaneously reduce greenhouse gases—including methane—while mitigating underwater noise, vessel strikes, air and water pollution, and effluent discharge. Advancements in energy efficiency, propulsion systems, and materials can deliver co-benefits across environmental and operational dimensions.

S4S: What policy or regulatory changes are most urgently needed to prevent a long-term “methane lock-in” in the shipping industry?

What is urgently needed now is clarity, consistency, and implementation. The IMO’s inclusion of methane emissions in its mid-term measures was critical, but short-term actions must now reflect the long-term decarbonization trajectory. According to the IPCC, global methane emissions must fall by one-third by 2030 and by nearly half by 2050 to maintain a 1.5°C pathway, an outlook that underscores there is a limited role for methane-based fuels in a zero-emissions future. In our opinion, the most pressing regulatory gap lies in ensuring that life-cycle assessment methodologies and emission factors accurately reflect real-world fuel performance and externalities – including methane leakage, short-term warming potential (GWP20), and the social, environmental, and health impacts. Without fully accounting for these factors, methane-based fuels will continue to be misrepresented as low-carbon solutions, with their perceived cost advantage reinforced by short-term industry cost-optimization. This puts the sector at risk of investing in assets and infrastructure that may become prematurely obsolete. Short-term market choices, like methane fuels, do not align with long-term climate, regulatory and market projections – and that’s why advancing data, integrity, transparency, and accountability in LCA guidelines and emissions accounting is so important right now.

S4S: In your view, what would a truly methane-free maritime industry look like by 2050?

A maritime industry that would operate with clear life-cycle accountability and with the environmental, social, health and economic costs of energy and infrastructure fully considered. The sector would be guided by evidence-based regulations while investment frameworks would contemplate more than short-term cost optimization. Methane-free shipping would also reflect a just and equitable transition, one that safeguards human health, biodiversity, water, and food systems, and upholds the land and resource rights of Indigenous and rural communities affected by fuel production and supply chains. Ultimately, a methane-free future for maritime transport would represent a future-proof industry: one that has reduced systemic risk, strengthened policy and financial coherence, and redefined competitiveness through transparency, accountability, and real climate integrity.

S4S: What message would you share with shipowners, ports, and governments that remain hesitant to move beyond LNG investments?

LNG is a risky bet that is likely to end in economic penalties and, eventually, stranded assets. The apparent cost advantage of LNG reflects a short-term optimization strategy that is hyped up by the oil and gas industry, even though LNG does not have a durable climate or market position. The LNG market already faces structural and policy headwinds that are starting to impact confidence in LNG and reshape investment patterns. LNG-fuelled newbuilds will likely continue to rise despite mounting evidence suggesting that not all contracts will be fulfilled, and that a pivot toward electrification and other non-methane solutions is already underway. Shipowners must consider the very real possibility of being locked into assets that will require expensive retrofits or early decommissioning, with research estimating £113–185 billion in potential stranded asset losses across LNG-capable fleets. Clear regulatory intervention continues to be the gap, but that too is slowly starting to emerge. It’s time for shipowners, ports and governments to reduce risks and make responsible business and regulatory decisions by moving away from the methane-pathway trap.

MARBEM highlights that any regulatory framework aiming to achieve net-zero emissions must include three core policy instruments:

· A carbon-intensity measure that drives performance improvements;

· A global fuel standard that ensures credible, science-based differentiation among fuels; and

· A GHG pricing system that internalizes external costs and steers investment toward scalable low- or zero-carbon options such as wind, while prioritizing the funding of decarbonization efforts and investments in the global south, small island developing states (SIDS) and least developed countries (LDCs).

These must be guided by life-cycle (well-to-wake) assessment principles, ensuring decisions reflect full-system impacts rather than isolated emissions metrics.

The views presented are only those of the authors and do not necessarily reflect those of SAFETY4SEA and are for information sharing and discussion purposes only.

title: Companies sign MoU to advance marine antifouling coatings - SAFETY4SEA
description:
I-Tech AB and Guangdong Havey Advanced Materials Technology Co., Ltd. have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to collaborate on developing antifouling materials for marine coatings.
The two companies are also exploring the creation of a joint venture focused on increasing the availability of environmentally responsible marine coating ingredients, including biodegradable binders.
Increasing the proportion of biodegradable materials used in marine coatings is essential to the future development of sustainable marine coatings.
For example, biodegradable binders can enhance antifouling performance and reduce Volatile Organic Compound (VOC) emissions.
Together, we could provide the market with advanced, sustainable paint ingredient technologies that offer both effective antifouling protection and a reduced environmental footprint.
text:
I-Tech AB and Guangdong Havey Advanced Materials Technology Co., Ltd. have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to collaborate on developing antifouling materials for marine coatings.

The partnership builds on joint R&D efforts that began in 2024, including preliminary testing of coatings combining I-Tech AB’s Selektope and biodegradable resin binders, which have shown promising results. The two companies are also exploring the creation of a joint venture focused on increasing the availability of environmentally responsible marine coating ingredients, including biodegradable binders.

At I-Tech, sustainability and technological breakthroughs go hand in hand. The collaboration with Havey opens new opportunities in our pursuit of commercialising more sustainable, next-generation antifouling solutions for the maritime industry

… said Markus Jönsson, CEO, I-Tech.

As a chief component in coating systems, binders are a key factor in determining the principal characteristics of a paint product, both physical and chemical. Increasing the proportion of biodegradable materials used in marine coatings is essential to the future development of sustainable marine coatings. For example, biodegradable binders can enhance antifouling performance and reduce Volatile Organic Compound (VOC) emissions.

We are excited to join forces with I-Tech. Together, we could provide the market with advanced, sustainable paint ingredient technologies that offer both effective antifouling protection and a reduced environmental footprint. Our combined expertise will position us at the forefront of green marine technology

… commented Zhishen (Jason) Dong, General Manager, Havey.
